title: Culbin Forest Walks and Cycling

images.title: Richard Webb / Culbin Forest
images.caption: Another scene from this vast forest, taken at NH983608. Orienteers walking towards the race start deeper in the forest.

images.title: Anne Burgess / Culbin Forest
images.caption: A crossroads in the Culbin Forest with differing species at each side.

images.title: Mick Garratt / The Edge of Culbin Forest
images.caption: The Edge of Culbin Forest. Alongside a barn of the farm, Wellhill.

images.title: Mick Garratt / Culbin Forest
images.caption: The forest was planted in the 1920s on an area of notorious everchanging sand dunes. The trees have now stabilised the sand.

images.title: Gary Rogers / Channel Through Salt Marsh - Culbin Sands
images.caption: Channel Through Salt Marsh - Culbin Sands. As well as being important as a saltmarsh habitat, evidence of iron age and bronze age faience jewellery and pictish weaponry has been found here.

images.title: Dorothy Carse / Sands at The Bar, Culbin
images.caption: Sands at The Bar, Culbin. The sands in this square on the Moray Firth can only be seen at low tide.

images.title: Dorothy Carse / Salt marsh at Culbin
images.caption: Salt marsh at Culbin. Between the northeastern ridge of sand dunes and Culbin Forest is an area of salt marsh.

images.title: Dr Richard Murray / Footpath at Culbin Sands Nature Reserve
images.caption: Footpath at Culbin Sands Nature Reserve, looking towards the forest. The signpost indicates the branch path leading to the car park at Kingsteps

description: Enjoy a cycle or walk around this large coastal forest near Nairn.  There are a huge number of tracks to choose from including the easy Hill 99 trail which is waymarked. The route below begins at the car park at the Culbin Forest Nature Reserve and takes you around the forest on various tracks. The route includes a visit to the Culbin Sands Nature Reserve on the coast at Nairn. Here you can see a variety of coastal birds including  bar-tailed godwits, oystercatchers and knots. The route then heads back through the forest passing a series of idyllic woodland lochs before returning to the start point. Other highlights in the forest include the beautiful Findhorn Bay where you can see ospreys and seals at the river-mouth and a view over the water towards the village of Findhorn. You can also climb the Hill 99 viewpoint trail where there are fabulous views of the surrounding area from the top of the viewpoint tower. National Cycle Network Route route 1 runs just past the forest so there is scope for continuing your ride if you have time. The forest is located about 16 miles north east of Inverness.
